cellularAutomata.lattice
Class TwoDimensionalLattice

java.lang.Object
  java.util.AbstractCollection<E>
      java.util.AbstractList<E>
          java.util.ArrayList<Cell>
              cellularAutomata.lattice.TwoDimensionalLattice
All Implemented Interfaces:
Lattice, java.io.Serializable, java.lang.Cloneable, java.lang.Iterable<Cell>, java.util.Collection<Cell>, java.util.List<Cell>, java.util.RandomAccess
Direct Known Subclasses:
HexagonalLattice, SquareLattice, TriangularLattice
public abstract class TwoDimensionalLattice
extends java.util.ArrayList<Cell>
implements Lattice

A two-dimensional lattice. Extend this class to create a square, hexagonal, triangular, or any other two-dimensional lattice that can have its associated cells stored in a two-dimensional array.
The neighbors (in other words, the getNeighboringCells() method) are what make different two-dimensional lattices unique. For example, wrap around conditions may or may not be implemented in the getNeighboringCells() method; and the neighborhood could be set up as triangular (three neighbors) square (4 neighbors), hexagonal (6 neighbors) or anything else (for example, variable numbers of neighbors in a non-regular lattice such as the "square-octagonal" lattice). Also note that we can implement lattices with next-nearest neighbors simply by changing the getNeighboringCells() method.
Note that by contract, all Lattices must have a constructor with the parameters String, Rule, int, and Properties. These are necessary for using reflection properly.

Author:
David Bahr
See Also:
Serialized Form

Field Detail

MAX_RECOMMENDED_CELLS

public static final long MAX_RECOMMENDED_CELLS
The maximum number of cells that the two-dimensional simulation should attempt before memory and speed become a problem.

See Also:
Constant Field Values
Constructor Detail

TwoDimensionalLattice

public TwoDimensionalLattice()
Default constructor required of all Lattices (for reflection). Typically not used to build the lattice, but instead used to gain access to methods such as getDisplayName() and getNumberOfNeighbors().

TwoDimensionalLattice

public TwoDimensionalLattice(java.lang.String initialStateFilePath,
                             Rule rule,
                             int maxHistory)
Create a two-dimensional cellular automaton with the same rule at all positions.

Parameters:
rule - The rule applied to all cells.
initialStateFilePath - The path to the file that specifies the initial state of the cellular automaton. If null, uses default initial state.
maxHistory - The maximum number of generations (or time steps) that will be remembered by the Cells on the lattice.
Method Detail

getCells

public Cell[] getCells()
Gets all of the cells that make up this lattice. No order is guaranteed but is generally obvious. Generally, for two-dimensional square lattices, the element array[row][col] is accessed at array[row * width + col].

Specified by:
getCells in interface Lattice
Returns:
The array of cells that make up this lattice.

getNumberOfNeighbors

public static int getNumberOfNeighbors(java.lang.String latticeDescription)
The number of neighbors for a cell on the current CA lattice. If the number of neighbors changes with lattice position, then this method returns -1. This utility method is not specific to two-dimensional lattices, and works equally well with one-dimensional lattices. It belongs in a base class, but that base class does not exist.

Returns:
The number of neighbors for a cell on the current lattice, or -1 if the number of neighbors changes with position.

setFileStorage

public void setFileStorage(FileStorage storage)
Sets the class that tells the lattice how to store its data in a file. Not necessary to set unless desired because a default is always provided.

Specified by:
setFileStorage in interface Lattice
Parameters:
storage - The storage class that tells the lattice how to save to a file.

setInitialState

public void setInitialState(java.lang.String filePathOrProperty)
Sets the state of all the cells on the lattice by reading values from a file. Assumes that the data is stored in a square two-dimensional array with each data point separated by a delimiter. May be overridden if necessary.

Specified by:
setInitialState in interface Lattice
Parameters:
filePathOrProperty - The path to the file containing the initial state of the automaton. For example, "C:/initial.data". May be a property value instead of a file path such as PropertyReader.STATE_BLANK, PropertyReader.STATE_SINGLE_SEED, or PropertyReader.STATE_RANDOM.
